whatever, me playing weird.

Another day, good things and bad things. It is what it is. Why don't we start with your stuff first, and then?

So let me, so what we've basically, what I basically have got is for, let's start with TPM and then we can go into the others. So for TPM, I've boiled it down to, oh, why don't I just share my screen? I've messed it up a little bit, so I'll send you the results later. Basically, I've identified one, two, these are the work units that we've identified so far. Architecture review, cost optimization analysis, creating a feature spec, creating a strategy spec, creating a technical teardown spec, incident response, process improvement, Quality checking in RCA, reviewing a milestone deliverable, triaging an issue, and working on a brain lift.

 I've created a separate one for overhead, just because I want you to track it. Maybe you are in line with that or not, but this is, for example, I noticed some people were having VPN authentication issues, blah, blah, right? I mean, these aren't really related work, but this is just, for example, me asking for a request for a team room access or whatever, right? I mean, anything, anytime where there's like not cognitive work isn't happening.

It's an interesting insight. I don't think about capturing it as a work and it should be a default, I guess. If we could do that as a default and say anything else is overhead would be good, but it's for sure better to state it. So I like the idea of starting with as an overhead because you acknowledge what's overhead and you take it from there. And refine. I don't think an MLM will have a super easy way of saying, oh, that's overhead, unless you can tell it specifically.



[Noumaan Shah] (2025-10-28T16:37:27.331Z)
That's what I'm telling you. That's what I'm telling it, right? I hear you. There are other ones which are not work units that have basically said, going to LinkedIn isn't a work unit. Going to Crossover isn't a work unit, right? And then being in a meeting isn't actually a work unit. But when you're in a meeting, you're doing something else that is related to that meeting, then that's, that is what you want to capture as a work unit.

 And then similarly, if you're doing coding, coding itself, isn't a work unit. You're doing coding because of something else. So what is it that you're doing? So that's a work unit.

But until then, it's just a tool.

 So I would apply the less is more here. Rather than creating a more complete control sheet, I would say this for sure changes how you look at data, the team structure. Work units also change how you look at data, goals. That's the thing where I would be like, can't AI do it? And that's why I would defer until we see that it sucks.
